title: Uninformative error message for incorrect placement of type annotations in tuple destructuring patterns

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

I made the mistake of attaching type annotations inside of a let-binding tuple destructuring pattern and was very confused for a bit.

Given the following code: ([Playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=b1f7bf2847707055b3abbf40b228d326))

```rust
fn foo() {
    // this doesn't compile! (the type annotations don't go in the destructuring pattern)
    let (a: u8, b: u8) = (8, 9);
    
    // correct code:
    let (a, b): (u8, u8) = (8, 9);
}
```

The current output is:

```rust
error: expected one of `)`, `,`, `@`, or `|`, found `:`
 --> src/lib.rs:2:11
  |
2 |     let (a: u8, b: u8) = (8_u8, 9_u8);
  |           ^ expected one of `)`, `,`, `@`, or `|`

error: expected one of `!`, `(`, `+`, `::`, `;`, `<`, or `=`, found `,`
 --> src/lib.rs:2:15
  |
2 |     let (a: u8, b: u8) = (8_u8, 9_u8);
  |               ^ expected one of 7 possible tokens
```

The output is very confusing and doesn't point users toward a solution. This error could be made by beginners, who would be confused, just as I was.

Ideally the output should have a help/did you mean box suggesting the second (correct) syntax for attaching type annotations.
